# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Special Instructions

None.

```julia
using DataFrames

function audi_filter(df_cars)
    df_audi = df_cars[df_cars.manufacturer .== "audi", :]
    df_audi_a4 = df_audi[df_audi.model .== "a4" || df_audi.model .== "a4 quattro", :]
    
    # Create a new column with boolean values indicating whether the car is an A4 or A4 Quattro
    df_audi_a4[:audi_a4_type] = true
    
    return df_audi_a4
end

# Example usage:
df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer = ["audi", "bmw", "mercedes"],
                   model = ["a4 quattro", "x3", "c-class"])

filtered_df = audi_filter(df_cars)
```

This function first filters the original DataFrame `df_cars` to only include rows with the manufacturer "audi". Then it further filters this subset to include only cars with model names "a4" or "a4 quattro". Finally, it creates a new column `audi_a4_type` and sets all values in that column to `true`, indicating that each row represents an Audi A4 or A4 Quattro.
